entities.text:
Next time you train a contrastive model in open_clip, give SigLIP a try: you may be able to train a larger and/or cheaper, slightly better model!

Or SigLiT to train a text model for a given pre-trained "semantic-free" image model like DINO or MAE.
arxiv.org/abs/2303.15343
Or use it to do vocabulary-free zero-shot with CaSED!
alessandroconti.me/papers/2306.00‚Ä¶
When OSS folks reimplement your paper before you manage to work on open sourcing it yourself üòçü´•

Sigmoid Loss for Language Image Pre-Training

Proposes a simple pairwise sigmoid loss for image-text pre-training that does not require a global view of the pairwise similarities for normalization with comparable perf to softmax.
arxiv.org/abs/2303.15343
There's a few more goodies in the paper:
arxiv.org/abs/2303.15343
We also used this recipe to train the largest base model for the amazing OWL-ViT v2 open-world detector:
arxiv.org/abs/2306.09683

We're trying to open-source before ICCVü§û

Co-authors tagged in OP. End ofüß∂

As a small-time ML builder/tinkerer, I'm incredibly thankful for models/research like this to be published openly.

Links:

‚Ä¢ Talk on YouTube:
youtu.be/Nk9YnMHB6hU?si‚Ä¶
‚Ä¢ Paper:
arxiv.org/abs/2303.15343
‚Ä¢ SigLIP on Hugging Face:
huggingface.co/google/siglip-‚Ä¶

Sigmoid Loss for Language Image Pre-Training [Zhai+, 2023, ICCV]
SigLip replaces CLIP's list-wise softmax loss with the pair-wise sigmoid, reducing memory consumption and improving accuracy when trained on limited batch sizes (<32k).
arxiv.org/abs/2303.15343
#NowReading

PaliGemma integrates a SigLIP image encoder with a Gemma-2B text decoder connected with a projection layer.

- SigLIP paper:
arxiv.org/pdf/2303.15343

Super excited about this!

Hey Lucas,
Are you familiar with metric learning (DML) literature?
Is SigLIP any different from the binomial deviance loss (and its many variations, like MS, PA), that is widely used in metric learning?

Hi, yes one of my most popular papers is actually in DML. However, to be honest, I hadn't heard the term "binomial deviance loss" before. Looking it up, indeed it is exactly the sigmoid cross-entropy loss. (In general, there's tons of parallels across communities here.)
Paper is very well detailed to be fair! Thanks for that!
its one and only

entities.name: Boris Dayma üñçÔ∏è
entities.text: @borisdayma
üôå
We actually explored using this "binary classification" alternative to the InfoNCE loss as a proxy for maximizing mutual information in the Deep InfoMax paper:
arxiv.org/abs/1808.06670
-- see the A.1 in the appendix about "JSD"

SigLIP is an absolute goated vision model üêê

I use it almost every day for zero-shot text-to-image matching.

For example, having a large folder of images and finding out which ones contain ‚Äúfood‚Äù using just the search term ‚Äúa photo of food‚Äù.

How?

SigLIP stands for ‚ÄúSigmoid Language Image Pretraining‚Äù.

In a nutshell, it‚Äôs a model that learns a joint representation of vision and language so the two become interchangeable.

The best part is that it‚Äôs open-source!

That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs also the vision backbone of many of the open-source VLMs coming out (Idefics3, PaliGemma, HPT-Edge).

For more on SigLIP and how it was trained, I‚Äôd highly recommend watching this talk from

entities.name: Lucas Beyer (bl16)
entities.text: @giffmana

, one of the co-creators of the model (where the slide is from).

(of course read the paper too but I find talks often contain little bits of information you may not pick up on in papers)

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: A screenshot showing a table with image-to-text matching probabilities in a demo titled 'A colab demo with brand-new examples'. The table compares various images, including an iPod, an apple, and a group of people, with corresponding descriptions. The row highlighted in green shows high accuracy (98%) for the match 'a photo of the SigLIP authors'. A presenter is visible in the bottom right corner of the screen, participating in the demo.

entities.text:
One of my favourite quotes from the talk was:

‚Äúthe more precise your text, the higher the score‚Äù

This pays big dividends when you‚Äôre sorting through a large dataset or doing precise image labelling.

As seen with the goat emojis demo, the more specific the text, the higher the score.

Demo notes: 
- I used Softmax but SigLIP can also use Sigmoid.
- Softmax = all text scores weighted against each other, scaled between 0 & 1 and add to 1 (usually a clear winner).
- Sigmoid = all text scores weighted individually (can be multiple winners).

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: Three images of a goat emoji are shown: Image 1 depicts a plain goat, Image 2 depicts the goat wearing a small top hat, and Image 3 depicts the goat wearing a top hat with small cows as roller skates. Below each image is a probability bar chart with three matching captions. For Image 1, the caption 'an emoji of a goat' has the highest probability (0.981). For Image 2, 'an emoji of a goat with a small top hat' has the highest probability (0.990). For Image 3, 'an emoji of a goat with a small top hat and small cows as roller skates' has the highest probability (0.966).

entities.text:
An open-source model like this opens up huge possibilities.

Such as... 

Custom dataset computer vision workflow*:

1. Start with large image dataset (e.g. COYO700M/DataComp-1B or larger if you have resources)
2. Embed images/texts with SigLIP -> index with FAISS (or similar) 
3. Define text ontology for precise extraction
4. Filter samples with zero-shot image/text matching
5. Use samples for downstream specific vision task improvement (e.g. to fine-tune a smaller vision model & deploy this to device, this is what I do at Nutrify)
6. ????
7. Profit
8. Bonus: Use filtered samples with SigLIP + image caption model + image generation model to generate even more task-specific samples

*should work quite well with any vision task you could reasonably expect to exist on the internet (e.g. if your task requires super specific custom vision data, this may not work as well)

What makes CLIP work?
The contrast with negatives via softmax?
The more negatives, the better -> large batch-size?

We'll answer "no" to both in our ICCV oralü§ì
By introducing SigLIP, a simpler CLIP that also works better and is more scalable, we can study the extremes.

Hop inüß∂

Perhaps surprisingly, we can replace the SoftMax-xent by a Sigmoid-xent loss in CLIP training and things just work.

With one little detail: add a learnable bias, much like the temperature.

This is conceptually simpler and cleaner: does image I and text T match: yes or no?

It's also much simpler code, and since every element in the similarity matrix is independent, makes it obvious that we can compute the loss "in chunks" across devices.

Chunked sigmoid loss never instantiates the full all-to-all matrix, hence letting us scale batch-size.

Surprisingly, we find that both SigLIP and CLIP both plateau at batch-sizes not much larger than 32k, originally used in CLIP.

We also investigate the LiT (
arxiv.org/abs/2111.07991
) setting, where we can reach batch-size of 1 Million. However, we see almost no benefit beyond 32k.

Next, we push efficiency to the extreme:

- With SigLiT we get to 80% ImageNet 0shot in just 1 day on 4 devices(!!)

- With SigLIP we get to 73% in 5 days on 32 devices. This is MUCH better than OpenAI (256 for 12 days?) and OpenCLIP (800? for ? days)

Here is a comparison to other notable CLIP models, just to convincingly show that this recipe is the best one publicly available right now.

We've actually been using it for quite some time internally before deciding to write up a paper about it, so we're confident here.

Two small bonus protips before the end:

Left: If your loss spikes, try reducing Adam/AdaFactor's beta2 to 0.95 (not novel, but rarely shared)

Right: When a piece of your model is pre-trained but not frozen, try not using any wd on it, but do use wd on the rand init'd pieces.
PS: Some of my screenshots in this thread are from the updated ICCV version that's not on arxiv yet, but will appear there later.
What is the metric for text-to-image retrieval results? Somehow can't find it in the text.
Top1 iirc. Oops, will fix thanks for asking !

ü•≥ Release of the open-source reproduction of CapPa
üéâ Beats every open-source model on all but one benchmark of SugarCrepe
üìï Apache 2 model weights
üëì Can be used as strong vision model for downstream tasks

üëâ Let‚Äôs dive in

CapPa is trained as a captioner and masked prediction on large noisy image/text dataset.

It represents an alternative to building vision models through classification (on ImageNet) or contrastive learning (like CLIP).

We mask the full caption 75% of the time ü§Ø

Intuitively, it helps in preventing the model from guessing the logical end of the caption from its start and rely more on the vision embeddings.

This helps in building a strong vision model for downstream tasks.

The model architecture is mostly similar to a ViT L/16 with a few tweaks.

We also use vision registers to provide a way for the model to encode global information without relying on local patches. Results in nice attention maps!

See "Vision Transformers Need Registers"

We beat every other open source model on SugarCrepe except for the category "Replace Object".

It matches results from the CapPa paper except they get slightly better metrics.

A big advantage of this model is that we have a clearer access to its knowledge.

Few samples:
- good at OCR
- great cultural knowledge
- hallucinate details (non-issue for downstream)
- likely leakage from near-duplicates

Full predictions (non cherry picked) in report

Even without being trained on classification/contrastive, the model is good at zero-shot prediction on ImageNet (63%).

We can further improve it with a quick training as a SigLiT model (frozen vision tower, text tower trained from scratch) to get to 74% top 1 / 93% top 5.
The model is mainly meant to be used as a vision tower for downstream tasks but you can play with it in the inference demo:
github.com/borisdayma/cli‚Ä¶
A port to ü§ó Transformers is being worked on.
See the full report for technical details, model weights, usage:
wandb.ai/craiyon/cappa-‚Ä¶
This project would not have been possible without Google TRC for the compute resources,

you once tweeted a paper link about setting beta_2 = 0.95 in Adam. Can you please remind me where this is?
Thank you üôè
Thanks! Reading your paper, I noticed the similarity.

Pleased to announce we are releasing checkpoints for our SigLIP models!

These are very strong image-text ViTs. We release them along with a colab to play around with. Most are english, but we also release a good i18n one.

Sorry, no magnet link mic drop. More in threadüß∂
The colab with checkpoints and code examples is in our big_vision JAX codebase:
github.com/google-researc‚Ä¶
Here's a table comparing to public models of the same size. The performance jump is significant, and we REMOVED near-duplicates of the benchmarks from our training data.

Here's some examples for the i18n model, which "gets" native cultural things. We're looking for more examples to test culture-language effects in i18n models.

Also, the long-standing grand challenge of computer vision, cow on beach, is finally solved!! Even in tuxedo :)

Note how we took/created over half of the images here ourselves, so they are clearly not in the training set, but the model still nails them, including reading some text.

Also, since it's a sigmoid and not softmax model, each score is independent of all others.
Finally, these models also contain a (trainable) bias, see our paper (
arxiv.org/abs/2303.15343
). It's an interesting parameter to play with, making the model more or less "trigger happy", play around with it to get some intuition.
Very cool work! Would love to have the checkpoints on hugging face hub!
Me too, but don‚Äôt have the time :) is standard ViT arch so should be straightforward.
When are you going to move to video? Improvements in image are becoming residual, while there is a lot of margin for video models.
Great question! I have some opinion on video that‚Äôs too long and nuanced for Twitter but I have given it a lot of thought over the years :)
Super cool! Isn't that the first open source model that was trained on WebLI ?
Yep!

A bit confused here. Why are you saying that the batch size is not part of the recipe for why CLIP works, and then show a figure that clearly shows that batch size does matter up to 32K, after which it plateaus? Same for the contrast stuff, sigmoid and softmax while different, both try to optimize for similar things, hence, there is still contrast being captured, but more so in a less coupled way, hence allowing for more flexibility. The latter is something used in segmentation literature often for example, and is known as a better alternative to softmax, among others that prove even more powerful (such as dice loss and focal loss).
Now this is how you market your paper to a modern audience - great work

Thanks for sharing, Ross. Your B/32 @ 256 (64) results are pretty strong! We will consider it for SigLIP as well :)
Thanks. Not mine though, I didn't work on the DataComp paper / project. Just tooting their horn as models maybe not the most visible as mentioned...

This is very cool - and I'm about to ask a very dumb question üòÇ. Does this loss have a strong assumption that image-text are a positive pair and all others in the batch are negative examples? And does this hold simply by the nature of the sampling scheme?

Not dumb. Yes it does assume all others are negative. And so does CLIP.  It‚Äôsa reasonable assumption for gigantic datasets.

This may be the reason they both level off and even deteriorate above ~32k-96k batch size and suggests we need more research here!
Interesting! I tried simple L1 and L2 losses this way several years ago and they just did not work, when SimCLR did. I presume you have similar conclusions?
I have not tried simclr, but was also wondering. Looks like Simon and Ting did at least try it a bit:
Why does SigLIP perform poorer for batch sizes of 96 and above? Any particular reasons?
x.com/giffmana/statu‚Ä¶
Does the per core batch size play a role here - would 32k on two cores behave separately from 32k on 64 cores?
very interesting paper, thanks for sharing. any intuition why both plateau at 32k?
Probably:

Trying to understand the reason for the delta in training time. Is this attributed to the loss term, or the fact that you‚Äôre computing the term over every pair in the batch? Or both?

My conclusion is each iteration squeezes more (compute available) information from the batch
The loss works a bit better and we can make much better use of hardware (fewer devices for same batch side) as we never materialize the matrix, leading to more efficiency.
All very nice results but I think it's worth noting that the dataset used (WebLI vs Laion2B vs WIT) makes a significant difference in the zero shot accuracies (see
arxiv.org/abs/2304.14108
for more on this)

Sure, which is why we run all experiments in the same apples to apples setting to avoid any confounders.

The "SOTA table" is the only exception, since it's about "if you take an of the shelf model, this is what you'd get".
Hopefully this improvement gets reproduced by openclip practitioners on other datasets.
Regarding openclip efficiency it's roughly on par with clip ones.

Fantastic! This is indeed much more friendly (compared with CLIP) to academia GPU servers that have no high-bandwidth communication. Looking forward to trained SigLIP models as well!
Been doing a big update to the clip-jax repo:
github.com/borisdayma/cli‚Ä¶

‚úÖ handle latest JAX/Flax API (jax arrays, pjit, shampoo, any type of model/activation sharding‚Ä¶)
‚úÖ chunked sigmoid loss

I got about 20-30% speed gain based on the model by upgrading to latest JAX/Flax API's and leveraging JAX arrays.

I've also been playing a lot with the profiler to ensure optimal sharding of operations. Sometimes minor rewrite to equivalent ops help the compiler with sharding

The chunked sigmoid loss was quite fun to implement (see "Sigmoid Loss for Language Image Pre-Training" paper).

By changing cross-entropy loss to sigmoid, we can now calculate total loss independently on each device without all-gather (mem + compute).
arxiv.org/abs/2303.15343
You basically calculate the loss on each device with its local data, and then iteratively swap data between devices to compute loss between negative examples and add it to your local loss.

This concept is very easy to implement in JAX with `shard_map`:
* it defines a function that happen on a single TPU
* loss initialized to local sigmoid between +/- samples
* iterate permuting image samples between TPU's, keeping text samples the same and adding negative loss

Overall this was a nice toy to play with `shard_map`.

It is especially interesting when you want to optimize your computation, whether for speed or memory, providing an easy way to define local input/output sharding and how it is performed.
I did some mini-tests and everything seemed fine (thanks

entities.name: Lucas Beyer (bl16)
entities.text: @giffmana

for paper clarifications).
On few devices, chunked loss is a bit faster than cross-entropy.
On many devices, you can fit a larger batch than you would have been able to.
Next step will be to train a base model with sigmoid loss to see how it differs from a model with regular contrastive loss.

Nice!
Did you observe meaningful speed up after saving one all-gather? 
Is there model degradation?

About 20% speed-up in term of time per training step but I've not trained fully a large model yet. I think they're supposed to require less steps. Also you can fit larger batch size.
Still need to train a larger model to really compare. I don't expect issues.

üì¢üì¢We release the SigLIP models to big_vision, pre-trained on WebLI, before our ICCV trip to Paris.

A SigLIP Base model achieves 79% 0-shot acc. on ImageNet, a Large model achieves 82% 0-shot acc. on ImageNet.

Demo:
colab.sandbox.google.com/github/google-‚Ä¶

arxiv.org/abs/2303.15343

entities.name: Lucas Beyer (bl16)
entities.text: @giffmana

, SigLIP is able to tell the difference between "a cold drink on a hot day" and "a hot drink on a cold day".

SigLIP is doing great on our favorite "a cow on the beach" example.

Try to slide the "Bias" bar to calibrate scores online!

Yes, we know everyone likes small models, so do us!

As recommended by the SoViT paper, we train a SigLIP model using the So400M vision backbone. The So400M model achieves 83.2% 0-shot acc. on ImageNet, outperforming larger released models.

Try it out and enjoy small models!

We care about i18n performance too. That's why we created the i18n WebLI dataset in the first place.

A mSigLIP Base model achieves 42.6% text-to-image 0-shot retrieval recall@1 across 36 langs on XM3600. This is on par with the current SOTA using a Large model.

We released a line of SigLIP Base models with different resolutions, including models from accepting 196 image patches to 1024 image patches. Let us know how these models perform in your projects.
